---
title: "Aesthetic Command Lines with Hyper, Spaceship, and Oh My Zsh"
description: "My fairly banal, basic, but beautiful command line setup"
startDate: "2024-10-05"
updated: "2024-10-05"
type: "note"
topics: ["Design", "Web Development"]
growthStage: "evergreen"
toc: false
---

After a recent accident with a pressurised water bottle on an airplane, I had to hard reset my Macbook. Or rather, the kind folks at the Apple Support desk reset it for me, after replacing the water-logged screen and logic board.<Footnote idName={1}>I wish I could tell you this was the first time it's ever happened to me, but it's not. AppleCare+ has paid for itself many times over.</Footnote>

Not a big deal, but it meant I had to go through setting up my local development environment from scratch. I've done this enough times that I have a checklist of things I usually run through. Most of these are boring; git, github, homebrew, node, yarn, python, etc.

The fun part is making the command line itself beautiful. I spend enough time in it that it matters whether it looks and feels right to me. I've settled on a combination of the [Hyper](https://hyper.is/) terminal, the [Spaceship](https://github.com/spaceship-prompt/spaceship-prompt) prompt, and [Oh My Zsh](https://ohmyz.sh/) for small conveniences. Here's what it looks like:

<BasicImage
	margin="0"
	width="880px"
	alt="My command line styled with hyper and spaceship"
	src="/images/posts/hyper.webp"
/>

Compared to most developers, this is a pretty minimal set of customisations, but it's enough for me; it's clean, minimal, and readable. I primarily use Hyper to handle the styling and colours. When you install Hyper, it'll automatically create a `.hyper.js` config file for you in your root directory. This is where you can tweak fonts, spacing, themes, and add plugins. You can open it in your standard code editor (VS Code, or whatever) by typing `code ~/.hyper.js` in the command line. Here's my full [hyper.js config file](https://gist.github.com/MaggieAppleton/f3fac1adda2bd8c365215f85e23a3416) if you want to see what I've customised.

The theme I use is [hyper-material-theme](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyper-material-theme) and the typeface is [JetBrains Mono](https://www.jetbrains.com/lp/mono/), both of which are free. You can browse plenty of other themes and plugins on the [Awesome Hyper](https://github.com/bnb/awesome-hyper?tab=readme-ov-file) repository.

		/>
	</svg>
</div>

I also use the Hyper plugin [hyper-statusline](https://github.com/henrikruscon/hyper-statusline) which adds a small bar to the bottom of the window with quicklinks to the working directory, the git commit hash, and number of dirty (uncommited) files. Clicking the former opens the directory in Finder, and the latter opens the commit on Github.

[Oh My Zsh](https://ohmyz.sh/) doesn't add much to the aesthetics here, but has [useful plugins](https://github.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/wiki/plugins) and makes installing Spaceship easy (described below). But I particularly like the [zsh-autosuggestions](https://github.com/zsh-users/zsh-autosuggestions) plugin which autosuggests commands and files based on your previous behaviour.

<BasicImage
	margin="0"
	width="880px"
	alt="Zsh autocomplete in the command line"
	src="/images/posts/hyper2.webp"
/>

[Spaceship](https://github.com/spaceship-prompt/spaceship-prompt) is what makes the prompt beautiful and shows me useful information like my current working directory, git branch, whether I have unstaged changes, and process run times. I just use their default prompt, but they offer an exessive number of configuration options.

Assuming you're using either Zsh or Oh My Zsh, you can set it via your `/.zshrc` file. You first need to clone the Github repo and symlink it, then set `ZSH_THEME="spaceship"` in the zshrc config file; instructions are on the [Github repo](https://github.com/spaceship-prompt/spaceship-prompt).

That's it. Nothing crazy complicated. Just a slightly nicer feeling command line experience.
